clean_content:
Definition / general

* Rare, benign, nonodontogenic, developmental extraosseous cyst that occurs in the soft tissue region between the base of the nose and the upper lip (region of nasolabial fold), lateral to the midline

Essential features

* Nonodontogenic cyst that presents as a painless, slow growing swelling in the nasolabial region, often causing nasal obstruction, facial asymmetry or elevation of the nasal ala; more common in middle aged women ([Braz J Otorhinolaryngol 2008;74:39](18392500))* On ultrasound, computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), appears as a well defined, extraosseous cystic lesion* Lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with goblet cells and a dense fibrous connective tissue wall* Diagnosis relies on clinical evaluation, imaging and histopathologic confirmation* Managed by complete surgical excision via a sublabial or transnasal approach, with low recurrence rates when fully excised; no malignant potential

Terminology

* Klestadt cyst ([Ann Otol Rhinol Laryngol 1953;62:84](13041056))* Nasal alveolar cyst* Nasoalveolar cyst* Nasal wing cyst* Nasal vestibule cyst* Mucoid cyst of the nose* Subalar cyst

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [K09.1](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/K00-K95/K00-K14/K09-/K09.1) - developmental (nonodontogenic) cysts of oral region* ICD-11: [DA05.Y](https://icd.who.int/browse/2024-01/mms/en#203165129%2Fother) - other specified cysts of oral or facial - neck region

Epidemiology

* Rare; ~0.7% of all maxillofacial cysts* Predominantly presents in adults; peak incidence in fourth to fifth decades of life* Higher prevalence in females; F:M = 3:1 - 4:1 ([Br J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2007;45:293](17030357))* Documented globally; no specific geographic predilection

Sites

* Depending on the cyst size, presenting symptoms and extent of documentation, the cyst may be variably characterized as arising within nasolabial fold or subnasal region with extension into maxillary vestibule or floor of the nose ([Braz J Otorhinolaryngol 2008;74:39](18392500))

Pathophysiology

* Cyst enlargement: mucin secretion by epithelial cells leads to progressive cyst enlargement ([J Craniofac Surg 2011;22:1946](21959477))

Etiology

* 3 main hypotheses, none unequivocally proven
  + Nasolacrimal origin: remnants of nasolacrimal duct ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2011;135:1499](22032581))+ Fusion anomaly: entrapped epithelial remnants along fusion line of medial nasal, lateral nasal and maxillary processes ([Ann Otol Rhinol Laryngol 1953;62:84](13041056))+ Disfavored: cystic expansion of regional nasal cavity seromucinous glandular tissue

Clinical features

* Presents as a painless, slowly enlarging mass most commonly centered in the nasolabial fold ([J Can Dent Assoc 2003;69:146](12622877))
  + Size: 1 - 3 cm+ Most common patient concern is swelling+ May cause elevation of the nasal ala and obliteration of the nasolabial sulcus, leading to facial asymmetry+ Intraorally can obliterate the mucolabial fold+ Potential for nasal obstruction or difficulty breathing through the affected nostril due to the mass effect* Most cases are unilateral but bilateral occurrences have been reported (~10%) ([Laryngoscope 2016;126:60](26153269))* Though typically asymptomatic, cysts can become infected, leading to pain and erythema in the region ([J Can Dent Assoc 2003;69:146](12622877))

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis of a nasolabial cyst involves the combination of clinical, imaging and microscopic findings
  + Clinical examination: initial assessment includes a thorough history and physical examination, focusing on characteristic features such as a painless swelling in the nasolabial fold, nasal obstruction or facial asymmetry+ Imaging: using 1 or more modalities (ultrasound, CT, MRI) to delineate location, size, internal characteristics, etc. ([Rhinology 1983;21:239](6635474))+ Histomorphology
        - Lined by multilayered or pseudostratified epithelium ([Head Neck Pathol 2013;7:155](23386223))- Occasional foci of other epithelial types are possible- Goblet cells are interspersed within the epithelial lining ([In Vivo 2012;26:453](22523298))- Cyst wall is composed of hypocellular fibrous connective tissue- Minimal to no hemorrhage- Presence of goblet cells leads to accumulation of mucin within the cyst lumen

Radiology description

* Aside from subtle blunting or superficial surface saucerization of bone, bone changes should not be identified with this soft tissue cyst* Imaging demonstrates that nasolabial cysts are extraosseous, with no evidence of bone extension* Ultrasound
      + May be a valuable initial imaging modality, offering high sensitivity (95%) and accuracy (95%) in identifying nasolabial cysts+ Delineates the cyst location, size and internal characteristics without radiation exposure+ Appearance: anechoic, well defined area between the nasolabial fold and maxillary bone* CT
        + CT scans provide additional detailed information on the cyst relationship to adjacent bony structures as well as location, shape and size+ CT shows sensitivity of 80% and accuracy of 80%+ Appearance: well defined, low density lesions located in the soft tissue between the nasolabial fold and maxillary bone* MRI:
          + MRI offers soft tissue contrast, aiding in assessment of extent and relationship to surrounding soft tissues+ MRI shows sensitivity of 85% and accuracy of 85%+ Appearance: hypointense on T1 weighted images and hyperintense on T2 weighted images, consistent with fluid content ([J Int Med Res 2023;51:3000605221147201](36597377))

Radiology images

Subtle scalloping of bone

[![Ultrasound appearance](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabialRadTh2.jpeg)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9830098/figure/fig1-03000605221147201/)

Ultrasound appearance

[![MRI appearance](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabialRadTh3.jpeg)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9830098/figure/fig3-03000605221147201/)

MRI appearance

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabial_nih01.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4253288/figure/F3/)

Lateral cephalograph

Prognostic factors

* Overall prognosis for nasolabial cysts is excellent, with rare instances of recurrence ([Clin Otolaryngol 2024;49:102](37818679))* Malignant transformation has not been reported

Case reports

* 33 year old man with swelling after rhinoplasty ([Aesthetic Plast Surg 2015;39:888](26392372))* 40 year old woman with chronic nasal obstruction ([J Surg Case Rep 2021;2021:rjab017](33732421))* 76 year old woman with 20 year history of lip swelling ([Gerodontology 2021;38:317](33590916))

Treatment

* Sublabial excision: traditional surgical approach involves complete surgical excision via an oral sublabial incision ([Clin Otolaryngol 2024;49:102](37818679))* Transnasal endoscopic marsupialization: an alternative, minimally invasive method ([Clin Otolaryngol 2024;49:102](37818679))

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabial_nih02.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4253288/figure/F1/)

Raised left ala of nose

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabial_nih03.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3927353/figure/F1/)

Extraoral swelling

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabial_nih04.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4253288/figure/F2/)

Obliteration of labial sulcus

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabial_nih05.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3642254/figure/Fig1/)

Endoscopic view

Gross description

* Size: 1 - 3 cm in diameter* External surface: if the cyst is removed intact, it appears as a smooth surfaced, fluctuant and well circumscribed mass ([J Surg Case Rep 2023;2023:rjad011](36727121))* Cut surface
      + Sectioning reveals a unilocular cavity filled with clear or yellowish mucoid fluid+ Wall is generally thin, with cyst lining appearing uniform and without internal surface papillary projections+ In the absence of inflammation or infection, solid areas or septations are unexpected

Gross images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabial_nih06.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4253288/figure/F5/)

Surgical specimen

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Cyst epithelial lining
  + Lined by multilayered or pseudostratified epithelium ([Head Neck Pathol 2013;7:155](23386223))+ Occasional foci of other epithelial types are possible
      - Stratified squamous epithelium, likely metaplastic or potentially incidentally incorporated oral mucosa- Cuboidal to columnar epithelium is possible+ Focal snouting of epithelium may be interpreted as apocrine change; however, extensive apocrine change may suggest an alternate diagnosis, such as apocrine hidrocystoma* Other features within the cyst epithelium
    + Cilia versus microvilli: presence of bona fide cilia has been described but remains debated+ Goblet cells are interspersed within the epithelial lining ([In Vivo 2012;26:453](22523298))* Cyst wall
      + Cyst wall is composed of hypocellular fibrous connective tissue+ Minimal to no hemorrhage+ Depending on size of cyst and extent of resection, occasional foci of cartilage, scant bone, skeletal muscle and seromucinous / salivary lobules may be incorporated from nearby anatomic sites ([Head Neck Pathol 2013;7:155](23386223))+ Varying degrees of acute or nonspecific chronic inflammatory cell infiltration ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2011;135:1499](22032581))+ Inflammation can impact epithelium with alterations, including squamous metaplasia+ Cyst wall lacks skin appendages such as hair follicles or sebaceous glands, helping to distinguishing it from other cystic lesions* Luminal contents
        + Presence of goblet cells leads to accumulation of mucin within the cyst lumen+ No evidence of compact keratin debris in lumen

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Kelly Magliocca, D.D.S., M.P.H.

Virtual slides

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Nasolabial cyst](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillanasolabialVirTh01.png)](https://vmicro.iusm.iu.edu/virtual_dent/nasolabial_cyst.html)

Nasolabial cyst

Positive stains

* [p63](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp63.html): nuclear positivity in basal epithelial cells ([In Vivo 2012;26:453](22523298))* [CK5/6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck5.html): expression in basal epithelial cells* [CK7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html): suprabasal cells* [CK19](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck19.html): full thickness epithelium* [MUC5AC](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html#muc5ac271810): positive in goblet cells within the cyst lining* [Mucicarmine](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmucins.html): positive in goblet cells within the cyst lining

Negative stains

* [CK20](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck20.html) ([In Vivo 2012;26:453](22523298))* [MUC2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)

Electron microscopy description

* Epithelial lining: bilayered to multilayered columnar epithelium with luminal microvilli and interspersed goblet cells* Surface features: instead of well developed cilia, the epithelial cells more commonly exhibit irregular microvilli on their surfaces; epithelial cilia are ill developed ([Laryngoscope 2006;116:307](16467725))* Intercellular junctions: adjacent epithelial cells display small grooves (microsulci) between them, with cytoplasmic processes extending from the lateral borders to contact adjacent cells

Sample pathology report

* Left nasolabial region, excision:
  + Benign cyst lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium, consistent with nasolabial cyst

Differential diagnosis

* [Nasopalatine duct cyst](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillanasopalatine.html):
  + Nonodontogenic cyst that represents the most common differential diagnostic consideration for nasolabial cyst+ Location: anterior maxilla, usually midline ([Dermatol Surg 2011;37:392](21314800))+ Intraosseous cyst; however, if bony cortical perforation has occurred, then a sampling of the soft tissue extension of the cyst lining could create a diagnostic dilemma, particularly in the absence of radiology+ Microscopic
          - Nearly identical to nasolabial cyst- Contents of incisive foramen are typically identified in the surgically resected specimen (peripheral nerve, cartilaginous rests, vascular channels)* [Salivary duct cysts](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitysalivaryductcyst.html) / **ductal ectasia**:
    + Reactive salivary lesion+ Location: variable+ Extraosseous+ Microscopic ([J Dent Sci 2022;17:615](35028102), [Arch Otolaryngol 1971;94:19](5555867))
            - Background salivary gland tissue almost invariably- Lacks the homogeneous fibrous wall of nasolabial cyst- Simple cystic lesion, no papillary fronds- Epithelium cuboidal or bilayered columnar with cuboidal basal layer- Often with oncocytic metaplasia* [Epidermal inclusion cyst](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumornonmelanocytickeratinouscystepidermal.html):
      + Reactive cyst+ Location: variable+ Extraosseous more common than intraosseous+ Microscopic ([J Lab Physicians 2014;6:60](24696565))
              - Keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium- Luminal keratin debris* [Glandular odontogenic cyst](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaglandularodontogenic.html) ([Head Neck Pathol 2011;5:364](21915706)):
        + Developmental odontogenic cyst+ Location: variable, mandible more often than maxilla+ Intraosseous cyst+ Microscopic
                - Variable thickness epithelium including hobnail, tufting, mucous cells, clear cells* [Hidrocystoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumornonmelanocyticapocrinecystadenoma.html):
          + Adnexal cyst often of the face+ Extraosseous+ Microscopic ([Dermatol Surg 2011;37:392](21314800))
                - Uni or multilocular cystic lesion lined by columnar cells- With or without decapitation secretion- May contain mucin in lumen
